trans-unit.source: Release Notes
trans-unit.target: Release Notes

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Release Notes
trans-unit.target: Release Notes

trans-unit.source: This topic describes the new features in each release of <token>firstref_acs</token>, explains how each release of the product differs from its predecessors, and highlights any breaking changes that might affect code written for an earlier release.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes the new features in each release of <token>firstref_acs</token>, explains how each release of the product differs from its predecessors, and highlights any breaking changes that might affect code written for an earlier release.

trans-unit.source: March 2015 – Migrate ACS Namespaces to Google OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: March 2015 – Migrate ACS Namespaces to Google OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: ACS has implemented a feature to help ACS namespace owners migrate their Google identity provider configurations from OpenID 2.0 to OpenID Connect.
trans-unit.target: ACS has implemented a feature to help ACS namespace owners migrate their Google identity provider configurations from OpenID 2.0 to OpenID Connect.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Customers will have until June 1, 2015 to migrate their ACS namespaces to OpenID Connect and until Jan 1, 2017 to migrate their backend code to use OpenID Connect identifiers.</embeddedLabel> Failure to perform the appropriate action before each deadline will cause disruption to your applications.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Customers will have until June 1, 2015 to migrate their ACS namespaces to OpenID Connect and until Jan 1, 2017 to migrate their backend code to use OpenID Connect identifiers.</embeddedLabel> Failure to perform the appropriate action before each deadline will cause disruption to your applications.

trans-unit.source: For detailed guidance, see <link xlink:href="abed9a15-8466-4c3a-80e0-8fa24a3ea0f7" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Migrating ACS Namespaces to Google OpenID Connect</link>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed guidance, see <link xlink:href="abed9a15-8466-4c3a-80e0-8fa24a3ea0f7" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Migrating ACS Namespaces to Google OpenID Connect</link>.

trans-unit.source: June 2014 – Google Identity Provider Support
trans-unit.target: June 2014 – Google Identity Provider Support

trans-unit.source: As of May 19, 2014, new ACS namespaces cannot use Google as an identity provider.
trans-unit.target: As of May 19, 2014, new ACS namespaces cannot use Google as an identity provider.

trans-unit.source: ACS namespaces that used Google and were registered before May 19, 2014 are unaffected.
trans-unit.target: ACS namespaces that used Google and were registered before May 19, 2014 are unaffected.

trans-unit.source: This new limitation exists because Google is phasing out support for OpenID 2.0, which ACS depends on, and has closed registration for new applications.
trans-unit.target: This new limitation exists because Google is phasing out support for OpenID 2.0, which ACS depends on, and has closed registration for new applications.

trans-unit.source: Existing ACS namespaces that used Google will continue to work until April 20, 2015.
trans-unit.target: Existing ACS namespaces that used Google will continue to work until April 20, 2015.

trans-unit.source: If your application requires support for Google accounts, we recommend that you register your application with them directly.
trans-unit.target: If your application requires support for Google accounts, we recommend that you register your application with them directly.

trans-unit.source: If a user attempts to sign in to a new ACS namespace using their Google account, they will be redirected to an HTTP 400 error page.
trans-unit.target: If a user attempts to sign in to a new ACS namespace using their Google account, they will be redirected to an HTTP 400 error page.

trans-unit.source: July 2013 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: July 2013 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: To increase the availability and performance of ACS for all users, ACS has implemented a limit of 30 token requests per second for each namespace.
trans-unit.target: To increase the availability and performance of ACS for all users, ACS has implemented a limit of 30 token requests per second for each namespace.

trans-unit.source: If a namespace exceeds this limit for a prolonged period, ACS rejects token requests from the namespace for the duration of the interval and returns an HTTP 429 / ACS90055 "Too many requests" error.
trans-unit.target: If a namespace exceeds this limit for a prolonged period, ACS rejects token requests from the namespace for the duration of the interval and returns an HTTP 429 / ACS90055 "Too many requests" error.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="22b73867-4825-4c3f-927b-0ddd148d0566" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Service Limitations</link> and <link xlink:href="5ba09d76-7619-40e4-aa8d-ce3d5f3e77f8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Error Codes</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="22b73867-4825-4c3f-927b-0ddd148d0566" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Service Limitations</link> and <link xlink:href="5ba09d76-7619-40e4-aa8d-ce3d5f3e77f8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Error Codes</link>.

trans-unit.source: December 2012 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: December 2012 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: New Features
trans-unit.target: New Features

trans-unit.source: The December 2012 update of <token>secondref_acs</token> includes the following new features:
trans-unit.target: The December 2012 update of <token>secondref_acs</token> includes the following new features:

trans-unit.source: Support for federated single sign-out using the WS-Federation protocol
trans-unit.target: Support for federated single sign-out using the WS-Federation protocol

trans-unit.source: Web applications that use <token>secondref_acs</token> to enable single sign-on (SSO) with identity providers using the WS-Federation protocol can now take advantage of single sign out capabilities.
trans-unit.target: Web applications that use <token>secondref_acs</token> to enable single sign-on (SSO) with identity providers using the WS-Federation protocol can now take advantage of single sign out capabilities.

trans-unit.source: When a user signs out of a web application, <token>secondref_acs</token> can automatically sign the user out of the identity provider and out of other relying party applications that use the same identity provider.
trans-unit.target: When a user signs out of a web application, <token>secondref_acs</token> can automatically sign the user out of the identity provider and out of other relying party applications that use the same identity provider.

trans-unit.source: This feature is enable for WS-Federation identity providers, including Active Directory Federation Services 2.0 and <token>ms_acct</token>.
trans-unit.target: This feature is enable for WS-Federation identity providers, including Active Directory Federation Services 2.0 and <token>ms_acct</token>.

trans-unit.source: To enable single sign out, <token>secondref_acs</token> performs the following tasks for WS-Federation protocol endpoints:
trans-unit.target: To enable single sign out, <token>secondref_acs</token> performs the following tasks for WS-Federation protocol endpoints:

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> recognizes <system>wsignoutcleanup1.0</system> messages from identity providers and responds by sending <system>wsignoutcleanup1.0</system> messages to relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> recognizes <system>wsignoutcleanup1.0</system> messages from identity providers and responds by sending <system>wsignoutcleanup1.0</system> messages to relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> recognizes <system>wsignout1.0</system> and <system>wreply</system> messages from relying party applications and responds by sending <system>wsignout1.0</system> messages to identity providers and <system>wsignoutcleanup1.0</system> messages to relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> recognizes <system>wsignout1.0</system> and <system>wreply</system> messages from relying party applications and responds by sending <system>wsignout1.0</system> messages to identity providers and <system>wsignoutcleanup1.0</system> messages to relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="6074c9da-92d0-458c-a86d-be38a0ac53c5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Code Sample: ASP.NET MVC 4 with Federated Sign-out</link> and <externalLink><linkText>Passive Authentication for ASP.NET in WIF</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/magazine/ff872350.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="6074c9da-92d0-458c-a86d-be38a0ac53c5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Code Sample: ASP.NET MVC 4 with Federated Sign-out</link> and <externalLink><linkText>Passive Authentication for ASP.NET in WIF</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/magazine/ff872350.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Discontinue support for ACS 1.0
trans-unit.target: Discontinue support for ACS 1.0

trans-unit.source: Support for Access Control Service 1.0 is discontinued in this release, including support for migrating from Access Control Service 1.0 to Access Control Service 2.0.
trans-unit.target: Support for Access Control Service 1.0 is discontinued in this release, including support for migrating from Access Control Service 1.0 to Access Control Service 2.0.

trans-unit.source: Navigating to <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s in new Azure Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Navigating to <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s in new Azure Management Portal

trans-unit.source: The new <externalLink><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><linkUri>https://manage.WindowsAzure.com</linkUri></externalLink> (http://manage.WindowsAzure.com) includes a route to the familiar ACS Management portal where you create and manage <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.
trans-unit.target: The new <externalLink><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><linkUri>https://manage.WindowsAzure.com</linkUri></externalLink> (http://manage.WindowsAzure.com) includes a route to the familiar ACS Management portal where you create and manage <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.

trans-unit.source: To navigate to the ACS Management portal:
trans-unit.target: To navigate to the ACS Management portal:

trans-unit.source: Click an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, and then click <ui>Manage</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, and then click <ui>Manage</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Navigating to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> for a service bus
trans-unit.target: Navigating to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> for a service bus

trans-unit.source: When you create a Service Bus namespace in the <token>portal</token>, the portal automatically creates an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> for the service bus.
trans-unit.target: When you create a Service Bus namespace in the <token>portal</token>, the portal automatically creates an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> for the service bus.

trans-unit.source: To configure and manage the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> for a service bus:
trans-unit.target: To configure and manage the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> for a service bus:

trans-unit.source: Log in to the <externalLink><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=275081</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the <externalLink><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=275081</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Service Bus</ui> and then select a service bus.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Service Bus</ui> and then select a service bus.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Access Key</ui> and then click <ui>Open ACS Management Portal</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Access Key</ui> and then click <ui>Open ACS Management Portal</ui>.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> is associated with the service bus, see the Service Namespace field at the top of the Access Control Service page.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> is associated with the service bus, see the Service Namespace field at the top of the Access Control Service page.

trans-unit.source: The namespace name consists of the service bus name with an "-sb" suffix.
trans-unit.target: The namespace name consists of the service bus name with an "-sb" suffix.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="1b45d8b4-ec59-47a9-a211-cf50cb5d48d5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Manage the Access Control Namespace for a Service Bus</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="1b45d8b4-ec59-47a9-a211-cf50cb5d48d5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Manage the Access Control Namespace for a Service Bus</link>.

trans-unit.source: ACS management portal enhancements for viewing WS-Federation identity provider keys, hiding passwords
trans-unit.target: ACS management portal enhancements for viewing WS-Federation identity provider keys, hiding passwords

trans-unit.source: This release contains a pair of enhancements related to viewing and working with certificates, keys, and passwords in the ACS 2.0 management portal:
trans-unit.target: This release contains a pair of enhancements related to viewing and working with certificates, keys, and passwords in the ACS 2.0 management portal:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Signing certificates are now visible in the Edit WS-Federation Identity Provider section</embeddedLabel> – Previously, certificates imported from WS-Federation metadata used to validate the signature of tokens issued from that identity provider were not visible in the ACS Management portal.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Signing certificates are now visible in the Edit WS-Federation Identity Provider section</embeddedLabel> – Previously, certificates imported from WS-Federation metadata used to validate the signature of tokens issued from that identity provider were not visible in the ACS Management portal.

trans-unit.source: The Edit WS-Federation Identity Provider section now displays information about imported certificates, including their expiration dates and status.
trans-unit.target: The Edit WS-Federation Identity Provider section now displays information about imported certificates, including their expiration dates and status.

trans-unit.source: These certificates can now be refreshed using a new “Reimport data from WS-Federation metadata URL upon save” checkbox.
trans-unit.target: These certificates can now be refreshed using a new “Reimport data from WS-Federation metadata URL upon save” checkbox.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Passwords and symmetric signing keys are now hidden by default</embeddedLabel> – To prevent unintentional disclosure of passwords and symmetric keys, these values are now hidden by default on the Edit screens throughout the portal.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Passwords and symmetric signing keys are now hidden by default</embeddedLabel> – To prevent unintentional disclosure of passwords and symmetric keys, these values are now hidden by default on the Edit screens throughout the portal.

trans-unit.source: To intentionally display the value of a password or symmetric key (for example, so it can be copied into an application), a “Show Password” or “Show Key” button must now be pressed.
trans-unit.target: To intentionally display the value of a password or symmetric key (for example, so it can be copied into an application), a “Show Password” or “Show Key” button must now be pressed.

trans-unit.source: Ability to Federate Directory Tenants with <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s
trans-unit.target: Ability to Federate Directory Tenants with <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory tenants can now be used as identity providers in <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory tenants can now be used as identity providers in <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.

trans-unit.source: This enables many scenarios such as enabling your web application to accept both organizational identities from directory tenants and consumer identities from social providers such as Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, Microsoft accounts or any other OpenID provider.
trans-unit.target: This enables many scenarios such as enabling your web application to accept both organizational identities from directory tenants and consumer identities from social providers such as Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, Microsoft accounts or any other OpenID provider.

trans-unit.source: You can find detailed instructions on how to implement the scenario in this post, <externalLink><linkText>Provisioning an Azure Active Directory Tenant as an Identity Provider in an ACS Namespace</linkText><linkUri>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vbertocci/archive/2012/11/07/provisioning-a-directory-tenant-as-an-identity-provider-in-an-acs-namespace.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: You can find detailed instructions on how to implement the scenario in this post, <externalLink><linkText>Provisioning an Azure Active Directory Tenant as an Identity Provider in an ACS Namespace</linkText><linkUri>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vbertocci/archive/2012/11/07/provisioning-a-directory-tenant-as-an-identity-provider-in-an-acs-namespace.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: SAML 2.0 Protocol Support for Relying Party Applications (Developer Preview)
trans-unit.target: SAML 2.0 Protocol Support for Relying Party Applications (Developer Preview)

trans-unit.source: ACS now supports the SAML 2.0 protocol for issuing tokens to relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: ACS now supports the SAML 2.0 protocol for issuing tokens to relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: SAML 2.0 protocol support has been released as a developer preview, meaning that details of the SAML 2.0 protocol implementation are still subject to change.
trans-unit.target: SAML 2.0 protocol support has been released as a developer preview, meaning that details of the SAML 2.0 protocol implementation are still subject to change.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see<externalLink><linkText>Developer Preview: SAMLProtocol</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj818292.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more details, see<externalLink><linkText>Developer Preview: SAMLProtocol</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj818292.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Known Issues
trans-unit.target: Known Issues

trans-unit.source: In the December 2012, <token>firstref_acs</token> update, the following known issues have been identified:
trans-unit.target: In the December 2012, <token>firstref_acs</token> update, the following known issues have been identified:

trans-unit.source: Azure Co-Administrators can now manage <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.
trans-unit.target: Azure Co-Administrators can now manage <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.

trans-unit.source: However, an action is required to propagate pre-existing co-administrators to a pre-existing <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.
trans-unit.target: However, an action is required to propagate pre-existing co-administrators to a pre-existing <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.

trans-unit.source: Prior to the November 2012 update, we resolved an issue where, by default, only the primary Azure service administrator could manage <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s created in the subscription.
trans-unit.target: Prior to the November 2012 update, we resolved an issue where, by default, only the primary Azure service administrator could manage <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s created in the subscription.

trans-unit.source: If an Azure co-administrator attempted to access the ACS Management Portal for an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, they would receive one of the following ACS error codes:
trans-unit.target: If an Azure co-administrator attempted to access the ACS Management Portal for an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, they would receive one of the following ACS error codes:

trans-unit.source: ACS50000: There was an error issuing a token.
trans-unit.target: ACS50000: There was an error issuing a token.

trans-unit.source: ACS60000: An error occurred while processing rules for relying party using issuer ‘uri:WindowsLiveID’
trans-unit.target: ACS60000: An error occurred while processing rules for relying party using issuer ‘uri:WindowsLiveID’

trans-unit.source: ACS60001: No output claims were generated during rules processing.
trans-unit.target: ACS60001: No output claims were generated during rules processing.

trans-unit.source: This issue is now resolved for new <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s created by any Azure service administrator or co-administrator.
trans-unit.target: This issue is now resolved for new <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s created by any Azure service administrator or co-administrator.

trans-unit.source: However, customers with namespaces that existed prior to the fix need to perform the following workaround for co-administrator data to propagate to those namespaces:
trans-unit.target: However, customers with namespaces that existed prior to the fix need to perform the following workaround for co-administrator data to propagate to those namespaces:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure portal (https://windows.azure.com/) using service administrator or account administrator credentials.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure portal (https://windows.azure.com/) using service administrator or account administrator credentials.

trans-unit.source: Remove and re-add the co-administrator, using the guidance in <externalLink><linkText>How to Add and Remove Co-Administrators for Your Azure Subscriptions</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/gg456328.aspx</linkUri></externalLink> (http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/gg456328.aspx)
trans-unit.target: Remove and re-add the co-administrator, using the guidance in <externalLink><linkText>How to Add and Remove Co-Administrators for Your Azure Subscriptions</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/gg456328.aspx</linkUri></externalLink> (http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/gg456328.aspx)

trans-unit.source: Sign out and sign in to the Azure portal using the co-administrator credentials.
trans-unit.target: Sign out and sign in to the Azure portal using the co-administrator credentials.

trans-unit.source: You will then be able to manage the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.
trans-unit.target: You will then be able to manage the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s.

trans-unit.source: September 2012 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: September 2012 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: In September 2012, <token>firstref_acs</token> received an update that contained the following changes:
trans-unit.target: In September 2012, <token>firstref_acs</token> received an update that contained the following changes:

trans-unit.source: The entityID published in the WS-Federation metadata emitted by ACS is now consistently lowercase
trans-unit.target: The entityID published in the WS-Federation metadata emitted by ACS is now consistently lowercase

trans-unit.source: The “entityID” attribute in the WS-Federation metadata published by <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s is now always lowercase.
trans-unit.target: The “entityID” attribute in the WS-Federation metadata published by <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s is now always lowercase.

trans-unit.source: In previous releases, it used the letter case that was entered when the namespace was created in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: In previous releases, it used the letter case that was entered when the namespace was created in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: The “entityID” attribute identifies the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to relying party applications, and below is an example of the attribute:
trans-unit.target: The “entityID” attribute identifies the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to relying party applications, and below is an example of the attribute:

trans-unit.source: This change was required to address potential token validation issues in which the letter-case of the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> in the <token>secondref_acs</token> -issued token (which is always lower case) does not match the letter-case of the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> imported by the relying party.
trans-unit.target: This change was required to address potential token validation issues in which the letter-case of the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> in the <token>secondref_acs</token> -issued token (which is always lower case) does not match the letter-case of the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> imported by the relying party.

trans-unit.source: Relying parties that use Windows Identity Foundation are not affected by the case-sensitivity issues.
trans-unit.target: Relying parties that use Windows Identity Foundation are not affected by the case-sensitivity issues.

trans-unit.source: X.509 Certificates uploaded to ACS now have a public key size restriction of 4096 bits
trans-unit.target: X.509 Certificates uploaded to ACS now have a public key size restriction of 4096 bits

trans-unit.source: All X.509 certificates uploaded to an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> via the ACS management portal or management service are now required to have a public key size that is no greater than 4096 bits.
trans-unit.target: All X.509 certificates uploaded to an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> via the ACS management portal or management service are now required to have a public key size that is no greater than 4096 bits.

trans-unit.source: This includes certificates used for token signing, token encryption, and token decryption.
trans-unit.target: This includes certificates used for token signing, token encryption, and token decryption.

trans-unit.source: In Windows, the public key size of a certificate can be checked by opening the certificate (.CER) file, selecting the “Details” tab, and checking the value of the “Public key” field.
trans-unit.target: In Windows, the public key size of a certificate can be checked by opening the certificate (.CER) file, selecting the “Details” tab, and checking the value of the “Public key” field.

trans-unit.source: Certificates that use the secure sha256RSA signature algorithm will have a 2048 bit public key.
trans-unit.target: Certificates that use the secure sha256RSA signature algorithm will have a 2048 bit public key.

trans-unit.source: Any existing certificates that have a key size of greater than 4096 bits will continue to work with ACS, but these certificates cannot be resaved in ACS until they are replaced with a compliant certificate.
trans-unit.target: Any existing certificates that have a key size of greater than 4096 bits will continue to work with ACS, but these certificates cannot be resaved in ACS until they are replaced with a compliant certificate.

trans-unit.source: Minor change to “primary key” selection algorithm that is used when ACS signs a token using an X.509 certificate
trans-unit.target: Minor change to “primary key” selection algorithm that is used when ACS signs a token using an X.509 certificate

trans-unit.source: In the ACS management portal and management service, there is a “Make Primary” field for token signing certificates that, when selected, causes ACS to sign tokens using that certificate.
trans-unit.target: In the ACS management portal and management service, there is a “Make Primary” field for token signing certificates that, when selected, causes ACS to sign tokens using that certificate.

trans-unit.source: With this release, if no configured token signing certificates have the “Make Primary” field checked, the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> will use the existing non-primary token signing certificate that has the earliest valid start date to sign the token.
trans-unit.target: With this release, if no configured token signing certificates have the “Make Primary” field checked, the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> will use the existing non-primary token signing certificate that has the earliest valid start date to sign the token.

trans-unit.source: ACS still does not sign tokens with a non-primary token signing certificate if a primary certificate exists, but is invalid or is expired.
trans-unit.target: ACS still does not sign tokens with a non-primary token signing certificate if a primary certificate exists, but is invalid or is expired.

trans-unit.source: JWT Beta: Change in signing behavior when using a global namespace certificate or key to sign a JWT token
trans-unit.target: JWT Beta: Change in signing behavior when using a global namespace certificate or key to sign a JWT token

trans-unit.source: When beta support for the JSON Web Token (JWT) format was released in June 2012, ACS used the following order of precedence to determine what key should be used to sign each JWT token issued to each relying party application:
trans-unit.target: When beta support for the JSON Web Token (JWT) format was released in June 2012, ACS used the following order of precedence to determine what key should be used to sign each JWT token issued to each relying party application:

trans-unit.source: Symmetric signing key assigned to relying party, if available
trans-unit.target: Symmetric signing key assigned to relying party, if available

trans-unit.source: X.509 signing certificate assigned to relying party, if available
trans-unit.target: X.509 signing certificate assigned to relying party, if available

trans-unit.source: Symmetric signing key assigned to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>
trans-unit.target: Symmetric signing key assigned to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>

trans-unit.source: X.509 signing certificate assigned to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>
trans-unit.target: X.509 signing certificate assigned to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>

trans-unit.source: As of this release, namespace-wide symmetric keys are no longer supported for signing JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: As of this release, namespace-wide symmetric keys are no longer supported for signing JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: Below is the new order of precedence for signing JWT tokens:
trans-unit.target: Below is the new order of precedence for signing JWT tokens:

trans-unit.source: Symmetric signing key assigned to relying party, if available
trans-unit.target: Symmetric signing key assigned to relying party, if available

trans-unit.source: X.509 signing certificate assigned to relying party, if available
trans-unit.target: X.509 signing certificate assigned to relying party, if available

trans-unit.source: X.509 signing certificate assigned to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>
trans-unit.target: X.509 signing certificate assigned to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>

trans-unit.source: June 2012 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: June 2012 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: In June 2012, <token>secondref_acs</token> received an update that contained the following new feature:
trans-unit.target: In June 2012, <token>secondref_acs</token> received an update that contained the following new feature:

trans-unit.source: JWT format now available for relying party applications (Beta)
trans-unit.target: JWT format now available for relying party applications (Beta)

trans-unit.source: This update introduces support for the JSON Web Token (JWT) BETA format in <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This update introduces support for the JSON Web Token (JWT) BETA format in <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: JWT is a lightweight, JSON-encoded token format that can be signed using an X.509 certificate or symmetric key, and can be issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> to relying party applications over any of the following protocols:
trans-unit.target: JWT is a lightweight, JSON-encoded token format that can be signed using an X.509 certificate or symmetric key, and can be issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> to relying party applications over any of the following protocols:

trans-unit.source: OAuth 2.0
trans-unit.target: OAuth 2.0

trans-unit.source: WS-Federation
trans-unit.target: WS-Federation

trans-unit.source: WS-Trust
trans-unit.target: WS-Trust

trans-unit.source: The JWT token format is now a selectable option in the Relying Party Applications section of the <link xlink:href="07b7daf4-b4d6-48fc-b921-3b1e63d44f61" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Portal</link>, and is also configurable through the <link xlink:href="f69b173a-fcf8-4f59-864a-09b05541d3df" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Service</link>.
trans-unit.target: The JWT token format is now a selectable option in the Relying Party Applications section of the <link xlink:href="07b7daf4-b4d6-48fc-b921-3b1e63d44f61" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Portal</link>, and is also configurable through the <link xlink:href="f69b173a-fcf8-4f59-864a-09b05541d3df" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Service</link>.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the JWT token format, see the <externalLink><linkText>JSON Web Token specification</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=253666</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the JWT token format, see the <externalLink><linkText>JSON Web Token specification</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=253666</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: ACS code samples that feature JWT tokens will be forthcoming at a future date.
trans-unit.target: ACS code samples that feature JWT tokens will be forthcoming at a future date.

trans-unit.source: JWT support is marked as “Beta” in <token>secondref_acs</token>, which means that all details of the JWT implementation are subject to change.
trans-unit.target: JWT support is marked as “Beta” in <token>secondref_acs</token>, which means that all details of the JWT implementation are subject to change.

trans-unit.source: Developers are encouraged to experiment with this token format.
trans-unit.target: Developers are encouraged to experiment with this token format.

trans-unit.source: However, JWT should not be used in production services, since the behavior may change without notice.
trans-unit.target: However, JWT should not be used in production services, since the behavior may change without notice.

trans-unit.source: May 2012 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: May 2012 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: In early May, 2012, <token>secondref_acs</token> received an update that contained the following change:
trans-unit.target: In early May, 2012, <token>secondref_acs</token> received an update that contained the following change:

trans-unit.source: Changes to entity ID properties exposed via management service
trans-unit.target: Changes to entity ID properties exposed via management service

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service currently exposes an ID property for each of the entity types it supports, as described in the <link xlink:href="9e564703-0a93-4ebe-8035-a5b8b54f57e9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Service API Reference</link>.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service currently exposes an ID property for each of the entity types it supports, as described in the <link xlink:href="9e564703-0a93-4ebe-8035-a5b8b54f57e9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Service API Reference</link>.

trans-unit.source: These ID properties are automatically set and managed by <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: These ID properties are automatically set and managed by <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: In this service update, <token>secondref_acs</token> is being migrated to a different database schema, and as a result these IDs exposed via the management service will change for all entity types.
trans-unit.target: In this service update, <token>secondref_acs</token> is being migrated to a different database schema, and as a result these IDs exposed via the management service will change for all entity types.

trans-unit.source: It is uncommon and generally not recommended that applications store or take a hardcoded dependency these IDs in order to query specific entities via the management service.
trans-unit.target: It is uncommon and generally not recommended that applications store or take a hardcoded dependency these IDs in order to query specific entities via the management service.

trans-unit.source: Instead, it is recommended that RelyingParty, ServiceIdentity, RuleGroup, and Issuer entity types be queried using the Name property, and other entity types be queried using a parent entity ID (e.g. RuleGroupId in the case of rules, or IssuerId in the case of identity providers).
trans-unit.target: Instead, it is recommended that RelyingParty, ServiceIdentity, RuleGroup, and Issuer entity types be queried using the Name property, and other entity types be queried using a parent entity ID (e.g. RuleGroupId in the case of rules, or IssuerId in the case of identity providers).

trans-unit.source: Changes to database collation for rules processing
trans-unit.target: Changes to database collation for rules processing

trans-unit.source: In order to expand support for international languages and to improve security, this release of <token>secondref_acs</token> updates the underlying SQL database collation used to compare input claims from SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS to Latin1_General_100_BIN2.
trans-unit.target: In order to expand support for international languages and to improve security, this release of <token>secondref_acs</token> updates the underlying SQL database collation used to compare input claims from SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS to Latin1_General_100_BIN2.

trans-unit.source: This change allows <token>secondref_acs</token> to support additional character sets and combinations of character sets.
trans-unit.target: This change allows <token>secondref_acs</token> to support additional character sets and combinations of character sets.

trans-unit.source: Applications relying on input claims containing strings with multiple character sets, not supported by SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS may see different or additional claims as a result of this new collation.
trans-unit.target: Applications relying on input claims containing strings with multiple character sets, not supported by SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS may see different or additional claims as a result of this new collation.

trans-unit.source: Customers wishing to take advantage of this new capability are encouraged to validate their applications for compatibility with the new SQL collation.
trans-unit.target: Customers wishing to take advantage of this new capability are encouraged to validate their applications for compatibility with the new SQL collation.

trans-unit.source: January 2012 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: January 2012 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: On January 25th, 2012, <token>secondref_acs</token> 2.0 received an update that contained the following changes:
trans-unit.target: On January 25th, 2012, <token>secondref_acs</token> 2.0 received an update that contained the following changes:

trans-unit.source: Change in ACS error responses for failed authentication requests
trans-unit.target: Change in ACS error responses for failed authentication requests

trans-unit.source: In the previous release, <token>secondref_acs</token> responded with different error codes when a client authenticated with a non-existent issuer (error code: ACS50026) or incorrect credentials (error code: ACS50006).
trans-unit.target: In the previous release, <token>secondref_acs</token> responded with different error codes when a client authenticated with a non-existent issuer (error code: ACS50026) or incorrect credentials (error code: ACS50006).

trans-unit.source: These error codes were previously emitted when a client attempted to authenticate using an invalid service identity name, or using a SWT or SAML token issued from an invalid identity provider.
trans-unit.target: These error codes were previously emitted when a client attempted to authenticate using an invalid service identity name, or using a SWT or SAML token issued from an invalid identity provider.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> will return error codes ACS50008, ACS50009 or ACS50012 for a failed authentication in the cases of SWT, SAML and username/password, respectively.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> will return error codes ACS50008, ACS50009 or ACS50012 for a failed authentication in the cases of SWT, SAML and username/password, respectively.

trans-unit.source: See the table below for details:
trans-unit.target: See the table below for details:

trans-unit.source: Authentication Response
trans-unit.target: Authentication Response

trans-unit.source: Before
trans-unit.target: Before

trans-unit.source: After
trans-unit.target: After

trans-unit.source: Non-existent Issuer
trans-unit.target: Non-existent Issuer

trans-unit.source: ACS50026 IssuerNotFound
trans-unit.target: ACS50026 IssuerNotFound

trans-unit.source: ACS50008 InvalidSwt,
trans-unit.target: ACS50008 InvalidSwt,

trans-unit.source: ACS50009 InvalidSaml, OR
trans-unit.target: ACS50009 InvalidSaml, OR

trans-unit.source: ACS50012 AuthenticationFailed
trans-unit.target: ACS50012 AuthenticationFailed

trans-unit.source: Incorrect Credentials
trans-unit.target: Incorrect Credentials

trans-unit.source: ACS50006 InvalidSignature
trans-unit.target: ACS50006 InvalidSignature

trans-unit.source: Change in OAuth 2.0 error codes for failed authentication requests
trans-unit.target: Change in OAuth 2.0 error codes for failed authentication requests

trans-unit.source: Also in the previous release, <token>secondref_acs</token> responded with different OAuth 2.0 error codes when a client authenticated with a non-existent issuer (invalid_client) or incorrect credentials (invalid_grant).
trans-unit.target: Also in the previous release, <token>secondref_acs</token> responded with different OAuth 2.0 error codes when a client authenticated with a non-existent issuer (invalid_client) or incorrect credentials (invalid_grant).

trans-unit.source: This behavior has also been updated, and <token>secondref_acs</token> will return invalid_request when the OAuth 2.0 request is malformed, invalid_client if the client fails authentication or the assertion provided for authentication is malformed or invalid, and invalid_grant if the authorization code is malformed or invalid.
trans-unit.target: This behavior has also been updated, and <token>secondref_acs</token> will return invalid_request when the OAuth 2.0 request is malformed, invalid_client if the client fails authentication or the assertion provided for authentication is malformed or invalid, and invalid_grant if the authorization code is malformed or invalid.

trans-unit.source: See the table below for details:
trans-unit.target: See the table below for details:

trans-unit.source: July 2011 Update Release Notes
trans-unit.target: July 2011 Update Release Notes

trans-unit.source: The release notes for the July 2011 update of <token>secondref_acs</token> 2.0 contains the following items:
trans-unit.target: The release notes for the July 2011 update of <token>secondref_acs</token> 2.0 contains the following items:

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: All <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s automatically receive the July 2011 update.
trans-unit.target: All <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>s automatically receive the July 2011 update.

trans-unit.source: This update contains no changes to the <token>secondref_acs</token> prerequisites for new or existing customers.
trans-unit.target: This update contains no changes to the <token>secondref_acs</token> prerequisites for new or existing customers.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the current <token>secondref_acs</token> prerequisites, see <link xlink:href="b52e98da-25cc-47d0-832f-a3ee58951524" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Prerequisites</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the current <token>secondref_acs</token> prerequisites, see <link xlink:href="b52e98da-25cc-47d0-832f-a3ee58951524" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Prerequisites</link>.

trans-unit.source: New Features
trans-unit.target: New Features

trans-unit.source: The July 2011 update to <token>secondref_acs</token> contains the following new features:
trans-unit.target: The July 2011 update to <token>secondref_acs</token> contains the following new features:

trans-unit.source: 1. Rules now support up to two input claims
trans-unit.target: 1. Rules now support up to two input claims

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine now supports a new type of rule that allows up to two input claims to be configured, instead of only one input claim.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine now supports a new type of rule that allows up to two input claims to be configured, instead of only one input claim.

trans-unit.source: Rules with two input claims can be used to reduce the overall number of rules required to perform complex user authorization functions.
trans-unit.target: Rules with two input claims can be used to reduce the overall number of rules required to perform complex user authorization functions.

trans-unit.source: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, a second input claim can be specified in a new rule by clicking <ui>Add a second input claim</ui> in the rule editor.
trans-unit.target: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, a second input claim can be specified in a new rule by clicking <ui>Add a second input claim</ui> in the rule editor.

trans-unit.source: In the management service, rules with two input claims can be configured using the <embeddedLabel>ConditionalRule</embeddedLabel> entity type.
trans-unit.target: In the management service, rules with two input claims can be configured using the <embeddedLabel>ConditionalRule</embeddedLabel> entity type.

trans-unit.source: Rules with one input claim are still configured using the <embeddedLabel>Rule</embeddedLabel> entity type for backwards compatibility.
trans-unit.target: Rules with one input claim are still configured using the <embeddedLabel>Rule</embeddedLabel> entity type for backwards compatibility.

trans-unit.source: For more information on rules with two input claims, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on rules with two input claims, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: 2. Localization in eleven languages
trans-unit.target: 2. Localization in eleven languages

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal and the <token>secondref_acs</token>-hosted login page for relying party applications now support localization in eleven written languages, including English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Russian, Spanish, Portuguese (Brazil), Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal and the <token>secondref_acs</token>-hosted login page for relying party applications now support localization in eleven written languages, including English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Russian, Spanish, Portuguese (Brazil), Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese.

trans-unit.source: An “English (International)” option is also available that uses an alternate date format for setting and displaying effective/expiration dates for keys.
trans-unit.target: An “English (International)” option is also available that uses an alternate date format for setting and displaying effective/expiration dates for keys.

trans-unit.source: The written language displayed for these user interfaces can be changed in one of the following three ways:
trans-unit.target: The written language displayed for these user interfaces can be changed in one of the following three ways:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Language Selector</embeddedLabel> – In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, the displayed language can be instantly changed using a new language selector menu that appears in the upper-right corner of the portal.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Language Selector</embeddedLabel> – In the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, the displayed language can be instantly changed using a new language selector menu that appears in the upper-right corner of the portal.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>URL</embeddedLabel> – The language displayed in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal can be changed by adding a “lang” parameter to the end of the request URL.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>URL</embeddedLabel> – The language displayed in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal can be changed by adding a “lang” parameter to the end of the request URL.

trans-unit.source: The legal values for this parameter are ISO 639-1/3166 language codes that correspond to a supported language.
trans-unit.target: The legal values for this parameter are ISO 639-1/3166 language codes that correspond to a supported language.

trans-unit.source: Examples values include en, de, es, fr, it, ja, ko, ru, pt-br, zh-cn, and zh-tw.
trans-unit.target: Examples values include en, de, es, fr, it, ja, ko, ru, pt-br, zh-cn, and zh-tw.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal URL with a parameter setting the displayed language to French:
trans-unit.target: Below is an example <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal URL with a parameter setting the displayed language to French:

trans-unit.source: https://your-namespace.accesscontrol.windows.net/?lang=fr
trans-unit.target: https://your-namespace.accesscontrol.windows.net/?lang=fr

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Web Browser Preferences</embeddedLabel> – If the “lang” URL parameter or language selector has never been used to set a language preference, then the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal and <token>secondref_acs</token>-hosted login pages will determine the default language to display based on the language preferences set in the web browser settings.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Web Browser Preferences</embeddedLabel> – If the “lang” URL parameter or language selector has never been used to set a language preference, then the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal and <token>secondref_acs</token>-hosted login pages will determine the default language to display based on the language preferences set in the web browser settings.

trans-unit.source: Changes
trans-unit.target: Changes

trans-unit.source: The following are notable service behavior changes in this release:
trans-unit.target: The following are notable service behavior changes in this release:

trans-unit.source: 1. Encoding is now UTF-8 for all OAuth 2.0 responses
trans-unit.target: 1. Encoding is now UTF-8 for all OAuth 2.0 responses

trans-unit.source: In the initial release of <token>secondref_acs</token>, the character encoding set for all HTTP responses from the OAuth 2.0 endpoint was US-ASCII.
trans-unit.target: In the initial release of <token>secondref_acs</token>, the character encoding set for all HTTP responses from the OAuth 2.0 endpoint was US-ASCII.

trans-unit.source: In the July 2011 update, the character encoding of all HTTP responses is now set to UTF-8 to support extended character sets.
trans-unit.target: In the July 2011 update, the character encoding of all HTTP responses is now set to UTF-8 to support extended character sets.

trans-unit.source: Known Issues
trans-unit.target: Known Issues

trans-unit.source: The following is a known issue in this release:
trans-unit.target: The following is a known issue in this release:

trans-unit.source: Rule editor cannot display custom issuers that are not associated with identity providers
trans-unit.target: Rule editor cannot display custom issuers that are not associated with identity providers

trans-unit.source: Currently, the rule editor in the ACS Management Portal can only display claim issuers that are associated with an identity provider or <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the rule editor in the ACS Management Portal can only display claim issuers that are associated with an identity provider or <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: If a rule is loaded that references an issuer that does not correspond to either of these things, then the following error will be displayed:
trans-unit.target: If a rule is loaded that references an issuer that does not correspond to either of these things, then the following error will be displayed:

trans-unit.source: ACS80001: This rule is configured to use a Claim Issuer type that is not supported by the management portal.
trans-unit.target: ACS80001: This rule is configured to use a Claim Issuer type that is not supported by the management portal.

trans-unit.source: Please use the management service to view and edit this rule.
trans-unit.target: Please use the management service to view and edit this rule.

trans-unit.source: There are two supported scenarios where an issuer can exist without an associated identity provider in <token>secondref_acs</token>:
trans-unit.target: There are two supported scenarios where an issuer can exist without an associated identity provider in <token>secondref_acs</token>:

trans-unit.source: In an OAuth 2.0 delegation scenario, an issuer record is created in the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> by using the ACS Management Service, and this issuer does not have an associated identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In an OAuth 2.0 delegation scenario, an issuer record is created in the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> by using the ACS Management Service, and this issuer does not have an associated identity provider.

trans-unit.source: When an issuer is created for the purpose of asserting claims in a token request over the OAuth WRAP protocol, while using an identically-named service identity to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: When an issuer is created for the purpose of asserting claims in a token request over the OAuth WRAP protocol, while using an identically-named service identity to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Quotas
trans-unit.target: Quotas

trans-unit.source: As of this release, <token>secondref_acs</token> does not impose limits on the number of identity providers, relying party applications, rule groups, rules, service identities, claim types, delegation records, issuers, keys, and addresses that can be created for a given <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: As of this release, <token>secondref_acs</token> does not impose limits on the number of identity providers, relying party applications, rule groups, rules, service identities, claim types, delegation records, issuers, keys, and addresses that can be created for a given <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: Service Limitations
trans-unit.target: Service Limitations

trans-unit.source: For more information about service limitations, see <link xlink:href="22b73867-4825-4c3f-927b-0ddd148d0566" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Service Limitations</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about service limitations, see <link xlink:href="22b73867-4825-4c3f-927b-0ddd148d0566" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Service Limitations</link>.
